title: Cohn's theorem
summary: In mathematics, Cohn's theorem[1] states that a nth-degree self-inversive polynomial p ( z ) {\displaystyle p(z)} has as many roots in the open unit disk D = { z ∈ C : | z | < 1 } {\displaystyle D=\{z\in \mathbb {C} :|z|<1\}} as the reciprocal polynomial of its derivative.[1][2][3] Cohn's theorem is useful for studying the distribution of the roots of self-inversive and self-reciprocal polynomials in the complex plane.[4][5]
